DOC.HEAD: Government Seeks to Ease Heating Fuels Transportation Problems
DOC.TEXT: The Christmas weekend cold snap has stretched the nation's energy system to the maximum and created ``spot shortages'' of heating fuels in some areas, the Energy Department's chief of emergency preparedness said Saturday. ``At the moment we think we can get through this abnormally cold weather,'' without widespread energy shortages, but the outlook could darken if refineries break down or other unforeseen problems develop, said John J. Easton Jr. Easton, the assistant energy secretary for international affairs and energy emergencies, said the government was not considering imposing any price or allocation controls. Easton spoke to reporters at Energy Department headquarters during a break in a day-long meeting with about 80 representatives of oil companies, electric utilities, natural gas distributors, state energy offices and other federal departments. The meeting was called Thursday to exchange information about localized distribution problems and to consider easing federal rules affecting energy transportation. Easton said, for example, that the Department of Transportation was waiving certain limits on working hours by fuel truck drivers. The Energy Department has begun processing applications for waivers of the Jones Act, which prohibits the use of foreign ships to carry U.S. oil products in domestic waters, Easton said, adding that some exceptions could be granted so that foreign ships heading overseas with U.S. fuel products could reverse course to U.S. ports. Easton said the main problem in heating fuels as of Saturday afternoon was distribution of propane. ``In propane there are spot shortages, and it will be tight for the next 10 days or so,'' he said. Later he said these shortages were ``in many parts of the country,'' mainly the Northeast and Midwest. Easton said the department wanted to reassure the public that ``the federal government is concerned'' about the hardships posed by heating fuel shortages, and that it is actively trying to ``cut the red tape to relieve the bottlenecks.'' ``This is not an emergency,'' Easton said, stressing that supplies of heating oil and natural gas as of Saturday were adequate, although refineries were operating at maximum capacity to meet ``unprecedented demand'' for heating fuels. ``We do not expect any shortages in natural gas, although I can say the system is producing at the maximum at the present time,'' Easton said. He said some parts of Texas were experiencing ``rotating blackouts'' due to electricity shortages but that power supplies in most areas were generally adequate. Easton said the meeting was told by a National Weather Service official that extreme cold weather was expected to continue at least through the end of December in the Northeast but that some relief was likely soon for other regions. The January outlook was for abnormal cold in the north central states but less harsh conditions elsewhere, he said.
